content: This report summarizes the USDA's efforts to establish a national animal traceability system for rapid disease outbreak response. The economic value of national animal identification and traceability is acknowledged, but federal proposals have faced controversy within the U.S. cattle industry. The report discusses the background of animal ID and traceability, reviews arguments for and against a national system, and highlights unresolved issues in program development. Appendices provide a timeline of the U.S. National Animal Identification System (NAIS) and its successor program. On February 5, 2010, Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack announced the abandonment of the National Animal Identification System (NAIS) and the proposal of a new approach for animal disease traceability by the USDA. This decision came after reviewing claims and counter-claims of proponents and opponents of the national animal ID system, highlighting unresolved issues in program development. Additionally, the report includes a brief chronology of the development of the U.S. NAIS and a description of major international organizations involved in animal health and trade standards.
